occurrences.line_text: On Tromparts steed her mounted without stay,
That though she mounted were, yet he her made
And brauely mounted to his most mishap:
Mounted in Phoebus charet fierie bright,
But he was mounted in his seat so high,
With many towres, and tarras mounted hye,
Full nobly mounted in right warlike wize;
And being thereon mounted, forth did pace,
This said, they both a furlongs mountenance
She had not rid the mountenance of a flight,
And march not past the mountenaunce of a shot.
With merry note her loud salutes the mounting larke.
Whence mounting vp, they find purueyance meet
Her Helmet, to her Courser mounting light:
And mounting light his foe for lying long vpbrayes.
From loftie steede, and mounting in their stead
And mounting to her steede, bad Talus guide her on.
But tooke her steede, and thereon mounting light,
And mounting straight vpon a charret hye,
Like Eyas hauke vp mounts vnto the skies,
High reared mounts, the lands about to vew;
Who mocketh all my paine, & laughs the more I mourn.
As one that inly mournd: so was she sad,
And eke himselfe mournd at their mournfull plight,
But pyn'd, &; mourn'd, & languisht, and alone did weepe.
And mourn'd to see her losse before her eyne,
Then gins her grieued ghost thus to lament and mourne.
The which he shortly did, and Vna left to mourne.
Can chaunge my cheare, or make me euer mourne;
O who shall helpe me to lament, and mourne
Who her deare nourslings losse no lesse did mourne,
And all the way did inly mourne, like one astray.
In which captiu'd she many moneths did mourne,
And all the wooddy Nymphes did wayle and mourne.
For which I thus doe mourne, and poure forth ceaselesse teares.
For that mishap, yet seeing him to mourne,
Her mournefull plaintes, beguiled of her art,
His mournefull plight, is swallowd vp vnwares,
Their mournefull charet, fild with rusty blood,
And made ensample of their mournefull sight
For she had layd her mournefull stole aside,
And mournefull meed of ioyes delicious:
Her mournefull notes full piteously did frame,
Vnto his wonne, and with her mournefull muse
His mightie hart their mournefull case can rew,
Faire Pastorella, whose sad mournefull hew
Mournes inwardly, and makes to himselfe mone:
In middest of their mournfull Tragedy,
There mournfull Cypresse grew in greatest store,
And eke himselfe mournd at their mournfull plight,
But to declare the mournfull Tragedyes,
And gan to her her mournfull plaint to make,
Which turned hath great mirth, to mourning sad,
That much did ease his mourning and misfare:
Right sorrowfully mourning her bereaued cares.
And made such piteous mourning therewithall,
With a faire Mayden clad in mourning weed,
Mourning the rigour of her malady,
And spent it selfe in mourning, he at last
Through daily mourning, and nightly misfare:
Into her mouth they crept, and suddain all were gone.
At her wide mouth: but being there withstood
With bloudy mouth his mother earth did kis,
With gaping mouth at her ran greedily,
From leprous mouth on all, that euer writt:
From flaming mouth bright sparkles fierie red,
Wide gaped, like the griesly mouth of hell,
Ran through his mouth with so importune might,
But both the fruit from hand, and floud from mouth
They passing by, that griesly mouth did see,
And round about the pots mouth, bound the thread,
And loathly mouth, vnmeete a mouth to bee,
And loathly mouth, vnmeete a mouth to bee,
An hardy hart, and his wide mouth did gape
Which wont to stop the mouth thereof, that none
Into his mouth his maystring bridle threw,
Within his mouth a blacke spot doth appeare,
The horse in hand, within his mouth to looke:
Ne he his mouth would open vnto wight,
From dreadfull mouth of death, which threatned sore
Of his owne mouth, that spake so warelesse word,
In her owne mouth the food, ment for her chyld,
Her face was vgly, and her mouth distort,
Then from her mouth the gobbet she does take,
And in his wide great mouth away her bare,
Hong still vpon his melting mouth attent;
And greedy mouth, wide gaping like hell gate,
Looking each houre into deathes mouth to fall,
To saue her chylde, which in misfortunes mouth was plaste.
With open mouth, that seemed to containe
Appearing like the mouth of Orcus griesly grim.
Therewith he mured vp his mouth along,
And bloudie mouthed with late cruell feast.
And flaming mouthes of steedes vnwonted wilde
Their minds to pleasure, & their mouthes to dainty fare.
And hundred mouthes, and voice of brasse I had,
Vnlesse she chaunst their stubborne mouths to twitch;
Does mow the flowring herbes and goodly things,
And other whiles with bitter mockes and mowes
Of their proud beautie, and th'one moyity
And thy moyst mountaines each on others throng,
Of the sunbeames in moyst complexion,
Or of the clouds to moysten their roots dry;
Moystened their fierie beames, with which she thrild
Priuily moystening his horrid cheek.
By this the moystie night approching fast,
Till liuing moysture into smoke do flow,
Sought through the world, and suffered so much ill,
As much disdayning to the curbe to yield:
Yet she much whiter, but the same did hide
Much can they prayse the trees so straight and hy,
A litle glooming light, much like a shade,
Much daunted with that dint, her sence was dazd,
That detestable sight him much amazde,
Mixt with a murmuring winde, much like the sowne
Much grieu'd to thinke that gentle Dame so light,
And after him she rode with so much speede
Did much emmoue his stout heroï¿½icke heart,
Much rueth me; but now put feare apart,
And doubting much his sence, he thus bespake;
Much seemed he to mone her haplesse chaunce,
Much feared I to haue bene quite abhord,
To thinke that knighthood I so much should shame,
Much like, as when the beaten marinere,
Which with their presence faire, the place much beautifide.
That much was worne, but therein little red,
And her darke griesly looke them much dismay;
Nor too much to prouoke; for he would learne
And much reioyced in their bloudy fray:
But this same Monster much more vgly was;
To haue done much more admirable deedes.
At her so pitteous cry was much amoou'd
The knight much honord, as beseemed well,
Iwill reuele, what ye so much desire:
Isorrowed all so much, as earst I ioyd,
The knight much wondred at his suddeine wit,
The knight was much enmoued with his speach,
She graunted, and that knight so much agraste,
So much the dart of sinfull guilt the soule dismayes.
And much asswag'd the passion of his plight,
Much more then that, why they in bands were layd,
Whereat he wondred much, and gan enquere,
That with his largenesse measured much land,
Whom famous Poetes verse so much doth vaunt,
Much was the man encombred with his hold,
Did wonder much at her celestiall sight:
Came running in, much like a man dismaid,
Which I so much do vaunt, yet no where show,
Why then should witlesse man so much misweene
He wo[n]der would much more: yet such to some appeare.
Her swollen eyes were much disfigured,
Now by my head (said Guyon) much I muse,
Which who so wants, wants so much of his rest;
Receiu'd, as knight of so much worth became,
The man was much abashed at his boast;
And all delight does raigne, much more then this?
That vnto knighthood workes much shame and woe;
If wonted force and fortune do not much me faile.
And much ashamd, that stroke of liuing arme
That Guyon much disdeignd so loathly sight.
She would admit, albe the knight her much did pray.
And all though pleasant, yet she made much more:
Sir Guyon grudging not so much his might,
For much he wondred at that vncouth sight;
Ten times so much be numbred francke and free.
Or where hast thou thy wonne, that so much gold
Mammon was much displeasd, yet no'te he chuse,
The warlike Elfe much wondred at this tree,
There is: else much more wretched were the cace
He much reioyst, and courd it tenderly,
Certes, Sir knight, ye bene too much to blame,
Mote stead you much your purpose to subdew.
They wasted had much way, and measurd many miles.
Faire Sir at that, which ye so much embrace?
Whose wanton pleasures him too much did please.
That she much more then her owne life him lou'd:
How much to her we owe, that all vs gaue,
Here to record, ne much materiall:
Was much dismayed with that dreadfull sight:
And raysd him vp much stronger then before,
Whose mariners and merchants with much toyle,
That all the three thereat woxe much afrayd,
Much wondred Guyon at the faire aspect
He much rebukt those wandring eyes of his,
Much greater griefe and shamefuller regret
All had he lost much bloud through many a wound,
Exceeding much the state of meane degree,
Doth not so much reioyce, as she reioyced theare.
His feeling words her feeble sence much pleased,
And much more strangely gan to loue his sight,
Portly his person was, and much increast
Aye me, how much I feare, least loue it bee;
Of much more vncouth thing I was affrayd;
Her chearefull words much cheard the feeble spright
And sooth, it ought your courage much inflame,
But so her smart was much more grieuous bred,
Whereat she wondred much, but would not stay
For of a woman he should haue much ill,
Thus much afford me, ere that he did die
They wondred much, and shortly vnderstood,
Or keepe their cabins: much I am affeard,
But so much as doth need, must needs be counted here.
In mischiefe, was much moued at so pitteous sight.
His feeble eyne, with too much brightnesse dazed,
Much feared he, least ought did ill betide
Thought with that sight him much to haue reliued;
Much more then earst, and would haue algates riued
Much merueiled thereat, as well he might,
So much high God doth innocence embrace.
Him bet so sore, that life and sense did much dismay.
Which they so much mistooke, they tooke delight
That much they faynd to know, who she mote bee;
Though whilome far much greater then thy fame,
Ere rest he found. Much there he suffered,
For that same Brute, whom much he did aduaunce
In his disquiet mind was much dismayd:
And euer his faint hart much earned at the sight.
That cheareful word his weake hart much did cheare,
So shall your glory be aduaunced much,
As much disdeigning to be so misdempt,
That much Malbecco ioyed in his iollity.
For he was much affraid, himselfe alone to find.
For nothing so much pitty doth implore,
Much fairer, then the former, was that roome,
That much she muz'd, yet could not construe it
Though much emmou'd, but stedfast still perseuered.
Which seene, he much reioyced in his cruell mind.
She much was cheard to heare him mentiond,
That sight of such a chaunge her much dismayd.
Was much empassiond in her gentle sprite,
Thereto her feare was made so much the greater
That much she feard his mind would grow to some excesse.
And much the more, by that he lately wrought,
For which no seruice she too much esteemed,
Made her not yeeld so much, as due she deemed.
Yet otherwise much worse, if worse might bee,
And much vnlike, th'one long, the other short,
So much her malice did her might surpas,
So much they did, that at the last they brake
A Knight much better then thy selfe behight,
They did much more their cruelty encrease;
With which vaine termes so much they did the[m]; moue,
So much the more as she refusd to loue,
So much the more she loued was and sought,
Did all that youthly rout so much appall,
That when she saw, it did her much amate,
Which much augmented all their other praise.
O   Why doe wretched men so much desire,
That made them dreaded much of all men farre and nie.
Much was he grieued with that gracelesse chaunce,
Were much amaz'd the headlesse tronke to see
Much was Cambello daunted with his blowes,
Much more of price and of more gratious powre
Admir'd of all the people, and much glorifide.
So much more sorely to the ground he fell,
Much was he daunted with that direfull stound,
That much he gan his glorie to enuy,
Much wondred all men, what, or whence he came,
Which Cambell seeing, much the same enuyde,
For either doth on other much relie.
And much repynd, that both of victors meede,
He much more goodly glosse thereon doth shed,
So much the more her griefe, the more her toyle:
Sir Scudamour there entring, much admired
That needed much her weake age to desire,
He wondred much. But th'other thus can say;
To giue him ground, (so much his force preuayled)
And with meeke seruice and much suit did lay
The feare whereof seem'd much her to affray:
And each did other much bewaile and mone;
Which subtill sleight did him encumber much,
And pitty much his plight, that liu'd like outcast thrall.
The Prince did wonder much, yet could not ghesse
That much did ease his mourning and misfare:
Which sodaine accident him much dismaid,
She knew him not, but pittied much his case,
But wondred much at his so selcouth case,
That her great daunger did him much dismay.
At which he wondred much, when all those signes he fond.
Him calling theefe, them whores; that much did vexe
That those two Ladies much asham'd did wexe:
Yet so much fauour she to him hath hight,
Gan blame me much for being so vntrew,
Their like resemblaunce much admired there,
Thus gazing long, at them much wondred he,
That all men much admyrde her change, and spake her praise.
Thenceforth they much more furiously gan fare,
Who wondring much at that so sodaine fit,
Certes sir Knight[s], ye seemen much to blame,
Hath me much sorrow and much trauell cost;
Hath me much sorrow and much trauell cost;
Yet is the paine thereof much greater then the fee.
Much more then that, which was in Paphos built,
Yet much disdaining vnto him to lout,
Much more deformed fearefull vgly were,
Much dearer be the things, which come through hard distresse.
I much admyring that so goodly frame,
She wore much like vnto a Danisk hood
Of litle much, of foes she maketh frends,
But much more rare and pretious to esteeme,
Did fall in loue: yet this much fairer shined,
By which I hardly past with much adoe:
But much more aged was his wife then he,
Liagore, much praisd for wise behests;
For much more eath to tell the starres on hy,
For though their numbers do much more surmount,
Admyr'd her beautie much, as she mote well:
They all are wandred much; that plaine appeares.
His dreadfull heast, much lesse him match in fight,
Much was he moued at that ruefull sight;
But Sangliere disdained much his doome,
Much did that Squire Sir Artegall adore,
Whose great assembly they did much admire,
Yet was admired much of fooles, women, and boys.
And looke then how much it doth ouerflow,
Or faile thereof, so much is more then iust to trow.
Sith thou misdeem'st so much of things in sight?
Therewith the Gyant much abashed sayd;
And counterpeise the same with so much wrong.
To fill the other scale with so much wrong.
He much was troubled, ne wist what to doo.
But for so much as to my lot here lights,
He much was mou'd at so vnworthie shame,
Much did his words the gentle Ladie quell,
Much was the knight incenst with his lewd word,
But see how much her purpose was deceaued.
Much was the man confounded in his mind,
Much was she moued with the mightie sway
Whose presence all their troups so much encombred
So great her pride, that she such basenesse much abhord.
So much the greater still her anguish grew,
Therewith much comforted, she gan vnfold
Much did he maruell at her vncouth speach,
Yet thus much friendship she to him did show,
Great weaknesse, and report of him much ill,
Ne doffe her armes, though he her much besought.
And much lesse honour by that warlike kinde
That euen she her selfe much wondered
Or ill apayd, or much dismayd ye be,
She much was eased in her troublous thought,
She was reuiu'd, and ioyd much in his semblance glad.
Consisted much in that aduentures priefe.
He much admired both his heart and hew,
Since neither is endamadg'd much thereby.
By that proud dame, which her so much disdained,
Were moued much thereat, and twixt them fained,
Much was he grieued with that haplesse throe,
But much the more that to his hatefull foe
That his good steed, all were he much renound
Beheld, it much appald her troubled spright:
The gentle knights reioyced much to heare
Of pompous show, much more then she had told;
Straunge there to see, it did them much amaze,
And woxe inclined much vnto her part,
So much more then is that of powre and art,
But thine owne people do thy mercy prayse much more.
Much more it praysed was of those two knights;
Much was he moued with her piteous plight,
Good hart in euils doth the euils much amend.
Much greater then was euer in her weeting,
Much like in foulnesse and deformity
And much dismayd with that dismayfull sight,
Then gan she cry much louder then afore,
Through many perils and much way did pas,
Did much abash Sir Artegall to heare,
Too much am I to blame for that faire Maide,
And much did magnifie his noble name.
Much was the Ladie in her gentle mind
And much to gaine, a litle for to yield;
Did much the more augment, and made most vgly cases.
That her mis-shape much helpt; and her foule heare
She would it eeke, and make much worse by telling,
So much the more at him still did she scold,
That him did much renowme, and far his fame display.
For ye haue much adoe to deale withall.
Much was the Knight abashed at that word;
Vile recreant, know that I doe much disdaine
The comming of that so much threatned Knight,
And gan t'augment her bitternesse much more:
That euery action doth them much commend,
Much was I moued in indignant mind,
Much did Sir Calidore admyre his speach
He praysd it much, and much admyred it;
He praysd it much, and much admyred it;
Him much more now, then earst he gan admire,
Whereat Sir Calidore did much delight,
Is now him selfe in much more wretched plight;
His meanesse much, & make her th'others riches scorne.
There he him found much better then he was,
Them much abasht, but more him selfe thereby,
With which rude speach his Lady much displeased,
So much the more was Calepine offended,
So sore her sides, so much her wounds did bleede:
Was much emmoued at his perils vew,
Nor his fierce steed, that mote him much dismay,
Much was he then encombred, ne could tell
So much more wofull, as my wofull plight
Whence soone vpstarting much he gan repine,
Renowmed much in armes and derring doe:
And being such, were now much more increast,
The Lady, for that she was much in dred,
Vile cowheard dogge, now doe I much repent,
But the stout Prince, with much more steddy stowre
He much was daunted with so dismall sight;
The Prince much mused at such villenie,
Much did the Crauen seeme to mone his case,
Whereat much grieu'd against that straunger knight,
He therewith much abashed and affrayd,
He doubted much what mote their meaning bee,
That all men did her person much admire,
Oft whip her dainty selfe, and much augment her doole.
Exceeding much the measure of mans stature,
Was much more grieuous, then the others blowes:
And much lamented his calamity,
Was much asham'd, that with an hempen cord
His manly mynde was much emmoued therewithall.
That for these Carles to carry much more comely were?
And wondred much at Cupids iudg'ment wise,
How much (sayd he) more happie is the state,
They that haue much, feare much to loose thereby,
They that haue much, feare much to loose thereby,
And wish the heauens so much had graced mee,
That may perhaps you better much withall,
So forth he drew much gold, and toward him it driue.
And out of them to presse the milke: loue so much could.
He much was troubled at that straungers guize,
There he did see, that pleased much his sight,
That with her goodly presence all the rest much graced.
Much wondred Calidore at this straunge sight,
And graced her so much to be another Grace.
Excelling much the meane of her degree;
With which the Knight him selfe did much content,
And droue away their flocks, with other much disorder.
And mixed threats among, and much vnto her vowed.
This their request the Captaine much appalled;
They fall to strokes, the frute of too much talke:
Seeme much more louely in that darknesse layd,
And cruell rigour her did much molest;
In much delight, and many ioyes among,
That much he feared, least reprochfull blame
Besides the losse of so much loos and fame,
Much was the Lady troubled at that speach,
And seeing it, much wondred at the sight;
Reioyced much to see his captiue plight,
And much admyr'd the Beast, but more admyr'd the Knight.
Oft tempred is (quoth she) with muchell smart:
He had in armes abroad wonne muchell fame,
He did engraue, and muchell bloud did spend,
But minds of mortall men are muchell mard,
Regard of worldly mucke doth fowly blend,
And mou'd amisse with massie mucks vnmeet regard.
But mucky filth his braunching armes annoyes,
But all his mind is set on mucky pelfe,
Thereafter all that mucky pelfe he tooke,
That mucky masse, the cause of mens decay,
Engrost with mud, which did them foule agrise,
Informed in the mud, on which the Sunne hath shynd.
And there her drowned in the durty mud:
Vnmard with ragged mosse or filthy mud;
Huge heapes of mudd he leaues, wherein there breed
Of muddie water, that like puddle stanke;
By muddy shore of broad seuen-mouthed Nile,
But cruell Mulciber would not obay
Of Mulcibers deuouring element;
And Mulla mine, whose waues I whilom taught to weep.
And crownes and kingdomes to thee multiply.
So many children he did multiply;
That bad them to increase and multiply:
And euen to her foes her mercies multiply.
Thus as they words amongst them multiply,
Through his three double hands thrise multiplyde,
A multitude of babes about her hong,
Arriuing, him with multitude oppresse;
He with their multitude was nought dismayd,
Which lawlesse multitude him comming too
For they doe me with multitude oppresse,
And vnto euery thing did aunswere mum:
He mumbled soft, but would not all his silence breake.
Him slaies, drownes Lady Munera
Her name is Munera, agreeing with her deedes.
Did head against them make, and strong munificence.
Vnmanly murder, and vnthrifty scath,
Of spoyle and murder they gan arme byliue,
Abhorred Murder, who with bloudie knyfe
She did conceale, and murder her owne mynd;
And spoyld their houses, and them selues did murder;
Of murdred men which therein strowed lay,
And with most cruell hand him murdred pittilesse.
Till murdred by the friends of Gratian;
Of Guizor, by thee slaine, and murdred by thy slight.
She threw her husbands murdred infant out,
Murdred my men, and slaine my Seneschall;
And all her people murdred with outragious might.
And murdred cruelly by a rebellious Mayd.
And did acquite a murdrer felonous;
Direfull impatience, and hart murdring loue;
After his murdrous spoiles and bloudy rage allayd.
With murdrous rauine, and deuouring might
When I at her my murdrous blade did bend,
The world with murdrous spoiles and bloudie pray,
